Miss Genevieve Brown
crossed out:  ℅ Senator Theatre, Sacramento, Calif.   Broadway Theatre   Portland, Oregon

3rd. August '28
Dear Jennie,
Enclosed? please find
a couple of the A.P.C. powders. I promised you.
My recommendation is:
a good hat rum with lemon mist
then take some A.P.C. and hop straight 
into bed and pile the blankets etc. on and
keep on some until you get up in
the morning.
Be very careful you don't catch
a chill the next day or you will
be laid up in bed a few days if you do.
Yours Sincerely
Murray Lopez?
PS.
Put the A.P.C. powder on your tongue and then
drink the rum and lemon mist (Quite a good method.)

Sydney 14 12. 17
Miss Genevieve Brown St. Evins {Stosphail>]
Hope you are feeling better au revoir Bill
1- 18

Miss Genevieve Brown,
To "Ingenues" 
Hotel Anasonia
P. [?] Burg. Notol

P.O. Box 1448,
Durban, Jatal. S. A. 
23. H. 32.
Gene darling
Firstly I received your most welcome letter, this morning, and having easefully perused [some?], have come to the conclusion that my efforts were certainly not waisted, even though you say there are tons of other matters to be considered. One never knows what a meeting like ours might lead to, and after what you have stated, my hopes have risen thousands of feet. 
Secondly, I'm sorry to know you had to write two letters, and furthermore it was unnecessary for you to do so, because anything form you dear girl would be just too [marvellous?]. Here again is the "tenth" man calling, because all I have said, and write, is meant from the bottom of my heart.

So, dear Gene, you are wide awake, only you cannot realise that there are some genuine males in this world, though you have met thousands in your world wide travels, who no doubt have proved washouts. So you are finding things different when you meet one of the true kind. This said with no "blowing of trumpets" on my part, because since you left, although I have been very busy, my mind is not working in balancing fashion; with wild love thoughts of you.
Now, dear girl, you have said some fine things in your epistle, which may be too good for me, 'cause you have only known me a short while, but would suggest that we wait till you come back to [Dunbar?]. Things seem to be very indefinite regarding your movements, but I intend phoning

through at 12-30 today again. I say again, ' cause I phoned last evening at 4-15 to the Hotel, and the reply was that you had gone to the "Theater." In any case it would be impossible for me to get up to-morrow to see you; I have business with our new spoon factory, which can only be done on Sunday. It's a long story, to be explained fully when you come down, which I believe you are definitely doing.
"Thy old pen seems to be caving in," but it won't stop me" But: if you should not return on Monday or Tuesday I shall do all in my power to et up. Gene dear you may think this is not "10TB" man, but honestly, the whole thing in a nutshell - you know I left you on Wednesday to keep a business appointment, well that [man?] + self are going to Singapore and next month, and there is lots

to be done. All in connection with this factory business. I guess you can agree to hear further in this connection later.
Pat will probably be going up tonight, but I am meeting him just now, to give certain messages to you and also deliver this epistle, if he goes, on the other hand I shall post it.
Gene dear I certainly have not forgotten you, not even for a moment. Have not been out since you left, and your photo is framed and now hanging in my bedroom. I will not think of you just a little dear, but lots.
You shall certainly see me again dear, even if I have to loose everything by getting to you, but am banking on your return to Durban for the present. Going to meet Pat now, so cheerio, remembering, I love you.
Yours, Harry

To P.O. Box 1448 
Grace darling, 
Just a [[lucrid]?] note which I at will deliver for me, just to show you that I have not forgotten you for [[this]?] moment. It is just on two o'clock and for [[leave 2-15, so]?] must hurry. 
In short - until tomorrow - I simply cannot possibly arrange] I get up, for will explain temporarily till I see you tomorrow. And absolutely broken hearted at not being able to arrange it dear, but these accidents are evidently real to try up. Did not ring '[illegible] beer bottling all the while till now to try and arrange something. [illegible] Grace dear, just dying to see you tomorrow so please send a message by for where I can meet you as soon as you

arrive.
All my love till then, and remember when you are playing to-night that I shall be dreaming of you all night.
Love, in fact all of it dear girl
Yours. 
Harry

stamped envelope
postmark  DURBIN   APR 29 1932    4 PM    stamp  SOUTH AFRICA  2d POSTAGE
Miss Genevieve Brown
℅ "Ingenues."
Passenger per.
"Kenilworth Castle"
The Docks, Capetown

If undelivered return to H.M.L.
c/o P.O. Box 1748 Durban

P.O. Box 1448,
Durban,
29. H. 32.
Gene my darling
Yesterday evening and last night were two of the worst I have ever spent. Without me saying why, am sure you must understand the reason, Gene dear. All I could do, was sit with the old pips, and wonder over this wonderful meeting of one that I dearly love, and to think that you have been torn away from me, is truely too terrible, but am consoling myself, that the world is a very small place at times, and as I have already stated, should it be O.K. for us to come together. dearest, nothing can stop it. I say this dear 'cause I shall do all in my power to make our period of parting as short as possible. Of course next time I see you I shall never let you sail away again. It was awful

to see your sweet face gradually getting further and further away yesterday when you were drawing away, but that sight shall never be forgotten by me, dear Gene. I had to fight hard to prevent tears, moreso from diving in after you, 'cause I felt I may never see you again. Now Gene dear after saying all this, I wish to make you one promise; firstly though you must remember I shall never take an interest in any other as I did in you. The promise is that when the marrying time comes along, I am going to find out first where you are, and ask you before anyone else, if you want to, be my wife. No doubt you imagine that is saying an awful lot, but rest assured the difference I have found in you and other girls, is so beautifully marked, that, it is easy for me to say, I need you and you only.

The news Gene, nothing has happened since yesterday afternoon except that as I told you I went to my tailors about a couple of new suits, after you had gone. This afternoon I am going further into details about our factory, as things have been a little idle since the accident. Dad, I am pleased to say is recovering wonderfully, and after I had shaved him this morning he looked quite fine. The Doctor called as says he is very pleased, but perhaps he wont be up to another week yet. Sorry about this 'cause it means I won't be able to get him to liocon before you leave. Never mind Gene dear, I shall never never forget you. I leave with me lots dear, and think of me always, and remember too that Harry loves you most of all From yours lovingly, forever lonely till we meet again, love love love Harry.

Miss Genevieve Brown
c/o "Ingenues"
Passenger to London, 
H.M.S. "Kenilworth Castle",
The Docks
Cape Town

Darling Gene, 
As promised here are a few more lines, which I hope will please you dear. I love you and feel perfectly sure about it now. 
Have arranged about the photo for you Gene, and am posting some direct to the Kenilworth Castle at noon today, so please look out for it. Hope you think of me often by it dear as I always shall do, because your photo will hang in my room where I shall always see it. 
Gene dear, I am going off now to have a game of golf. Tonight I meet Pat, and have a chat. Then tomorrow golf and will write again Monday, and give you

all the news.
Looking forward to a note from you dear Gene, telling me what you have been doing with yourself, in the meantime remember I am determined to see you again soon 'cause I love you dearly. 
Yours forever Gene dear and it is terrible lonely here without you,
Love love love,
Harry.
File:Man in suit and tie on board a ship, other vessels in background

handwritten on back of photograph with corner torn off
ought you might missing this Gene. Taken on board when I went down to Capetown last week. Admit it's not of the best.   "HARRY"   9A330
"Harry"

envelope with postmark and stamp  DURBAN  MAY 2 1932  6 PM       SOUTH AFRICA 2d POSTAGE
Miss Genevieve Brown,
c/o "Ingenues"
Passenger to London per "Kenilworth Castle"
The Docks
Cape Town

P.O. Box 1448
Durban, Natal
S. Africa
2.5.32
Gene dearest,
I got your two lovely
letters this morning, and you have no idea how glad I was to get them. By all
you say it would appear as though
you + I are two of the most lonely 
people at present, having been
parted like this, dear.
No Gene I did not see
you cry, but did you really cry after 
I had left? Perhaps you shed a 
few wet drops the same as myself, 
having that terrible thought in my 
mind that you were beginning 
a very long journey which would 
eventually take you many many 
miles away, from me. Never mind
dear girl, just remember that your
Harry is always thinking of you 'cause
you are the one girl that agrees with

2
my idea of perfect.
Glad to hear from your
second letter that there is a chance
of moving to 2nd Class in CapeTown
after all it is not fair on you girls.
Re my news.  Saturday after-
noon our golf competition, which 
was played in a howling storm, and
all got wet though. Personally,
I played well  considering con-
ditions. Basil was the winner 
and as you will see from cutting
enclosed, I came third with the best
gross. Then Sunday it rained too
hard in the morning, so I stayed 
in bed until noon, lying thinking 
of you, - where you were and what
you might be doing -. In the after-
noon Basil + I played but it was
very wet, still it was exercise any-
way.
This morning I did the  the odd
spot of work, and went round to 
several of Dad's places. The latter

3
got up today and soon will be doing

his own duties, although at present 

I love doing them for him. 
That's about it for this one 
Gene dear, will write again tomorrow,

in the meantime goodbye sweetness.
All my love for you only,
Harry

envelope
postmark  DURBAN  MAY 3 1932    stamp   SOUTH AFRICA  2d POSTAGE
Miss Genevieve Brown
Passenger to London
c/o "Ingenues" per "Kenilworth Castle"
The Docks,
CapeTown

back of envelope
If undelivered return to H.M.L.
℅ P.O. Box 1748
Durban

℅  P. O. Box 1748,
Durban
3. 5. 32.
Gene darling.
Here goes again, as promised another short note for you, 'cause I love you. This will naturally be short Gene because there has only been last night since I posted, but all the same I promised to write every day until you leave Capetown, and I can always state what a wonderful girl I think you are and my love for you, eh!
Well anyway last night I went down to the Llangibby Castle to fetch a gentleman friend who travelled out with me from London, and took him home, where we had other visitors and all played cards. This particular gentleman friend is the aide-de-camp to the Gov. General of Uganda, and most charming fellow too. Tons to say for himself etc.

This morning I have done the usual, and called down to see Pat, to give him Thamar's message that you sent in my letter. Once again we chatted over things and both Pat & Phil think I am very lucky to have met with such a nice girl as you. Well I said, 'she is just too marvellous for words," and Gene dear I meant it with all my heart. My dear girl this town is simply empty for me now without you, so I think you had better come back soon.
Tonight I shall see Pat again, and he wants me to dance tomorrow night, but me, I am not going.
Am going to post this now to catch the mail, and I think tomorrow is the last mail with which to catch you, so cheerio dearest Gene until then. As always all my love and good luck. Remember me sometimes
love love love
Harry.

Gene dear have just received yours posted from Port Elizabeth, for which many thanks, and it has certainly shown me that you can write, when you want too, as in this case.
Grand idea this sweater making, and you know what Gene, if I could have that sweater made by your own hands, I should be the happiest man in the world. What about it? 
Sorry there is no more to say dear girl, 'cause I should like to go on writing for ever to you.
I love you also still. 
Harry

envelope
M81/128105  500/7/26  C&S/382  P. 539  EXPRESS
two postage stamps  SUDAFRIKA  1/. POSSELL   SUDAFRIKA  2d POSSELL
Miss Genevieve Brown,
℅ "Ingenues"Passenger per s.s. "Kenilworth Castle",
The Docks,
CAPE TOWN.

back of envelope  
IF UNDELIVERED RETURN TO H.M.L. 
P.O. BOX 1748
DURBAN
stamped  REGISTERED DURBAN  4 MAY 32   3 - 0 PM

P.O. Box 1748,
Durban, Natal S.A. 
4. 5. 32.
Gene my darling,
This is your farewell letter, and I have to post Express Letter to catch you. Its only a matter of hours now before you sail away from Sunny South Africa and lonely Harry. All I can suggest Gene, is that you live in hopes and expectation of my coming up any old time. That no doubt sounds a little indefinite dear, but it is as much as I can say now. You know that I shall do everything possible to try and see you again quickly, don't you Gene?
You will be pleased to hear that at 4-30 yesterday afternoon I went home and took Dad out for his first drive since the accident. He was very thrilled to be out again, and called at

2
his office, then on to the Club, where he enjoyed a short chat with some friends. This done he was very glad to turn in again to bed, as his legs were feeling a little weary. Soon he will be back to his duties though.
Well Gene dear I am looking forward to your news, and I shall be thinking lots about you, knowing all the while that my girl is soon to leave our shores, but I promise not to forget you dear, not even for the shortest space of time. Each week I shall write to you from today, and shall do so until I have other news from you.

  Never could I explain to anyone, how my idea of life has completely changed since meeting you, dear, and feel quite sure that it will have to be you for me and me for you. Your

3
charming little ways are so entirely different from any I have yet met, and I am absolutely fascinated with you in everything, so Gene dear if it pleases you, go away from here knowing that I want you, and I mean to have you some day.
Goodbye darling, with all the love in the world from me, your lonely loving sweetheart.
Harry

23rd
Dear Mother:
We landed this afternoon
about six o'clock in Plymouth.
This is the most old fashioned
town you ever saw n your
life. A person first can't believe
that it is real. We go to Brighton
on the Beach tomorrow where
we will play. The boat trip
was just wonderful. I was
only seasick one day and gosh
did I eat. It was a trench
boat and the serve about a nine
course dinner with wine and
believe it or not I ate every
course and drank wine with my
dinner. Moby? did get fat over

over here. I never felt so good in all my life and Genevieve is just a different person. I think the wine did us worlds of good. Oh yes a French gentleman from the French government invited Mrs. Lacey, [Thomas?] Lacey (the Australians Genevieve + myself to sit at his table this whole trip on the boat. Can you imagine that? It was quite an honor and we were rather proud of it. He was a perfect gentleman and we enjoyed his company very much. He kinda fell for [Thama?] and said if he were in Paris

when we got there he would show us a good time. We played for three benefits on the boat and wore our evening dresses - oh it was wonderful. Some very notable people were on the boat. Amelia Earhart the girl Aviator, Misha Elman the famous concert violin player, and different ambassadors from different countries. Mischa Elman gave a concert on the boat and I think he is wonderful - enjoyed every minute of it. Sure wish you could be with us. Every thing was to wonderful. We got thru customs with out a bit of trouble. They didn't even

open our trunks. You know this town is the Plymouth that Columbus left from to discover America and believe me I don't think a thing has changed since then. It doesn't get dark here until about 10 o'clock at night. We gained five hours coming over here. When it's 10 o'clock at night here it is only five o'clock in the afternoon at home. Well Mother I could tell you every thing. The scenery is perfectly gorgeous here and so green. Well will give you our London address and you

write there until I tell you different.
Love, Grace
Fosters Agency
Leicester Square - Theatre Chambers, London, England
c/o E. G. Sherman's "Ingenues"

Sunday. 
Tunis-Africa.
Dear Mother:
Read your letter yesterday and it sure was full of news. We've had the most exciting time here. We went to Carthage to see the old dug up cities. You know you have read them in history - they were covered up by an earthquake. It was wonderful. First will tell about the old Amphitheatre. It was the most interesting of all, the cage where the Christians were kept on one side and the other cage

for the lions. It's nearly impossible to describe it. There is a big wall built around the arena and on the outside of that are the seats for the spectators - the wall was built to keep the lions from the onlookers. The cages were built down about six steps with an arena around - the Christians were turned into the arena first and then the lions - it was impossible to believe all this, we also saw the theatre - none of these places were built with roofs on them all outdoor with marble columns etc. There is a huge stage to the theatre and the seats are [unclear] of slabs of marble built in stairs fashion right in the

earth. We saw a private home that was dug up and they were still excavating - had only been working on this since August and the Arabs were still digging. The floors of the home were marble, the wine cellar was not hurt at all - just as it was thousands of years ago, the bathroom, the bath in middle and dressing rooms on each side, big walls for their grain - a huge cistern and everything just as it was. We saw the old roman Cathedral - the last Eucharistic Congress was held there. There was a little grave yard in the church - we only saw the empty graves.

the mummied bodies had been taken up and put in Museums. We saw other old Christian churches. In one there was mosaic work that was there before Christ and a mosaic work that was laid after Christ - we went thru Arab summer resort where rich Arabs spend their summer. We went to coffee house where the Arabs squat on the floor and have coffee - no chairs or tables only mats on the floor. It was the most interesting trip yet. We went thru Arab village here in Tunis - it is very quaint. There is a big wall built around the village and it is only safe to go there in day time. They have what they call Souks. That is real narrow

streets. On one street will be where they make shoes - one shop after another nothing but shoe makers - on another brass makers etc. It was very interesting. I bought a table with a brass top. The legs fold up so I could pack it easily. Genevieve bought two big leather pillows - the kind you sit on we'll have to have them stuffed after we get home. Oh what a day. Yesterday they had a terrible storm - a typhoon - it was the

the most god awful thing I have ever seen. The rain coming down in sheets, the wind blowing, all the trees fell down, windows blown in, tops of automobiles blown off and the lights went out and we had to burn candles. We were supposed to give a matinee but the lights went out and we got out of that. Its raining today and you never saw such rain - it's their rainy season here and the natives say it is the worse yet. Well Mother I have to go to matinee so please write oftener. Ask Hollie if she ever got my letter - this
make two I have sent her. Write soon its terrible to go weeks without mail. Love, Grace
Longfellow's Home, Pittsfield, Mass. colored photo of Longfellow's home; cameo colored portrait of Longfellow on right side of postcard face

Dear Mother: Will write you a long letter soon. We have been up in Catskill Mts for a week and it has been beautiful. Will write
Mrs Gus Brown
Hardinsburg Ky
Electric Chair, Sing Sing Prison, NY  206,693 J.V. colored drawing/photo of electric chair

Mrs. Gus Brown
Hardinsburg Ky
Dear Mother: Entertained I [out?] boys at Sing Sin prison last evening and guards took us thru the place this morning. I even sat in chair that [Judd Shay?] and Ruth Snyder went to their death in. 
It was all very intersting.
Love, Grace

Mrs Grace Brown
Hardinsburg Ky
U.S.A.

Glasgow, Scotland
Aug 5th
Dear Mother: 
Well here we are in dear old
Scotland. It sure is quaint and odd.
We went out to see Loch Lomond today, 
and we saw Bullock Castle + Cameron
house. It was all very interesting by the
way I sent you some white heather in a box with the paid of the Royal Stuart. The white heather is supposed to bring good luck so let's hope it does. Tomorrow we are going to Edenborough to see the old castles etc. Genevieve is well and we have one more week in England. I'll give you our new address. Write often and dish all the dirt. Love, Grace Brown.
Wm Morris Agency
39 Ave des Champ Elysees
Paris France
c/o E.G. Sherman's "Ingenues"
Be sure and keep the heather
b&w photograph of unidentified/unnamed (Duomo di Milano) gothic cathedral

Milano Itlay
Mrs. Grace Brown
Hardinsburg Ky USA
Dear Mother: do not send any  more mail to Paris address, will send new address as soon as I get it. This is a picture of the Milan Cathedral and it is the most beautiful I have ever seen. We were in it this morning and from the picture you cannot really tell how beautiful it is. Will write you a letter. We crossed the Alps to get here. 
Love, Grace

Milan - Italy
October 9
Dear Mother: well who ever thought that we would be here. Sent you a picture of the cathedral and it is to beautiful to describe. It is made of marble and its the most beautiful piece of art I have ever seen. Every thing is marble here as this is the country where marble is found. we took a sight seeing trip and went to an old church to see the famous painting of "The Last Supper," we don't even know the first meaning of art at home and you surely realize it when you see these things that were painted centuries ago and are still as good as if they were only painted yesterday. We went to the famous grave yard of Milan and you would think you were in an art gallery. The monuments there are worth thousands and thousands of dollars - most of them are cut from one huge piece of marble and what a sight. Its impossible to into detail - you'd have to see it to appreciate the beauty. We went to several old churches and the (over)

works of art in them are unbelievable. When you stop to think of the age of them it nearly knocks you for a [row of pins?]. Our hotel is just across from the Milan Cathedral and we have to pass by it every time we go to the theatre. We crossed the Alps to get here and of course that was another beautiful spectacle. Wish we could go to Rome but we're luck to get here I guess. Am enjoying the trip. We had a bad panic leaving Berlin but every thing is working out all right so there is nothing to worry about. Sent Miss Hollie Walker a card of the Cathedral from here also Frankie.
We're getting so we can talk with our hands pretty good but most of the foreigners speak a little English. Well how goes things at home. We read terrible things in the papers about bank failures, etc. Write me all the news. Is Hollie still at home. Give my regards to every body. Things are in awful conditions over here, guess its the same the world over. Do not write to Paris address any more - will give new address. Genevieve has a bad cold and I've had the stomach ever since I 've been in Milan - the food does not

agree with me. I always thought you'd find spaghetti all over the space in Italy but its so hard to get and is terrible, not near as good as in the good old U.S.A. You can get wine or anything like that but I'd give most anything for a good old malted milk or ice cream soda. They don't know what those things are over here. 
Oh yes I forgot to tell you about the toilets on the street. They are terrible, They are for men and they don't have anything around them and you can see the men in there pissing for all they are worth. The people here think nothing of it but my eyes might near bulged out of my head when I saw them. They are on nearly every corner. You sure do see funny things in these old cities. Well Mother its getting late and I'd better go to bed. Write all the news. Will write new address on other page. Tell Hollie to write.
Love, Grace

c/o Gorring's Travel Agency
9A Green Street
Leicster Square
London WC2 England
c/o E.G. Sherman's Ingenues
Be sure to put enough stamp on to take it anywhere. 
I will write it plainer here.
c/o Gorring's Travel Agency
9A Green Street
Leicster Square
London WC2 England
c/o E.G. Sherman's Ingenues

Sat Nov 7th
Dear Mother:
Rec'd your letter yesterday, not much news to tell. We played in Hamburg last and sure did like Germany and hated to leave it. We're now in Paris and so far don't like it near as well as Germany. We went thru Belgium to get here and it was a very uninteresting country. It's rained most every day since we've been here I guess that's why I don't like it so far but after we see a few things I'll like it better. Today we took cab up Champs de Elysee and saw Magdalene Church and walked down thru

2.
Moonmarte-- that is the artists quarters similar to Greenwich Village in New York. We saw Arc de Triomphe and unknow soldiers grave which is in the Arc de Triomphe-- it has a light all ways burning and is very pretty. Things are terrible expensive here so am not going to buy any thing and I'm not terrible impressed with the clothes. Oh yes we saw Eiffel Tower from a distance and also the Loure but didnt go unclear Louvre. We expect to go out to Colonial Exposition about Tuesday so that should be intresting. also Notre Dame and a hundred other things. It sure

3.
is tiresome-- this sight seeing business, there is so much to see, I sure am glad that am fortunate enough to be seeing everthing-- we expect to go to Spain also to play in Nice, Monte Carlo and lord knows where else. Am not getting many souvenirs only small things, havn't seen anything much that I wanted or that you would want. Just can't get over Germany-- of all the places that is the only one I thought I wouldn't like. Well there really isn't much news. One of the girls was very sick in Hamburg with an awful throat-- they had to have her there in the hospital because they thought it was something contagious but I found out it was only very bad tonsils. She reaches here tomorrow night and you can bet we're glad because we were afraid we'd catch what she had but it was only false alarm so we're safe. 
Well write and dish all the dirt.
Write to the old address.
Love
Grace.
W.M. Morris Agency
39 Ave des Chomp-Elysees
Paris
France
unclear E.G. Shermans Ingenues.

1932
SOUTHERN RAILWAY.
seal with words "National Scheme for Disabled Men"
MARINE DEPARTMENT
Jan. 14th
Dear Mother:
Rec'd your letter this morning. We left Nice about six o'clock and arrived in Paris twelve today unclear until five in Paris and then caught train to Havre where we got boat to cross Channel to Southhampton, England and we get boat to South Africa. We are on the Channel boat now and sure dread the crossing it is always so rough. We'll be on African boat tomorrow night and will be on it for three weeks. Let's hope the trip is a smooth one. I just about wrote everything about Tunis and Carthage is just about half hours ride from Tunis. This Carthage is the same ancient Carthage in ancient history and was conquered by the Romans. It was so intresting about Monte Carlo it isn't in France

Its in a little country called Monaco. Monte Carlo is the only town and is the size of the country and is only about twice as large as H-Burg. It is owned and run by the Prince of Monaco and is protected by the French government. It has mountains all around and the sea on one side. The Casino (the gambling place) is the main thing there and its money comes from the wealthy tourists. We played in Nice for two weeks at the very best hotel and stayed there too. We played afternoon teas in Nice and at night went to Monte Carlo & played dinner dance but we played two weeks before in Monte Carlo so all together we were there for a month. I really liked Nice the best-- we met many intresting and wealthy people there. Well mother it will be some time

before you'll hear from me again so don't be worried.
Love 
Grace.

[[image of ox-drawn carriage sled; two men in business dress sitting in carriage; man in jacket and hat holding pole standing behind oxen and in front of sled carriage; man in work cloths standing in front of and looking at oxen; location is a curbside stone-paved street in front of an unidentified gated yard or park]]

Dear Mother, we landed here in Madeira unclear this unclear  This is place they unclear unclear Madeira linen and hand work you see the picture on unclear unclear and what will unclear in from boat to town.  This is all very interesting.  We are enjoying ourselves and unclear in S. Africa in 3 weeks. Love unclear
Addressed to: Mrs Grace Brown Hardinsburg Ky, U.S.A. image - Portuguese postage stamp, red 75C; double postmarked Africa House Funchal-Madeira; stamp postmarked unclear date, Madeira; USA postmark in violet ink; bottom/left of address, unclear, Feb 4

1932
TELEPHONES 7480-1-2
(PRIVATE EXCHANGE)
bERKELY HOTEL,
BREE STREET,
JOHANNESBURG.
South Africa.
Monday.
Dear Mother:
Well at last we are here in South Africa and we sure do like it-- it reminds me so much of down home. On the day we arrived the American Consul & Wife entertained us to an afternoon tea and garden party. There were about five hundred guests. All the Americans were there also and the Ladies and Sirs from England. The act is quite a success here-- after our first performance the Consul & wife took all of us to the Carlton Hotel (which is the hotel) for to be entertained. Yesterday they came & took us to tea at Country Club etc. I sewed all

2
day and didn't go but Genevieve went and they had a lovely time. We were on the boat for three weeks and enjoyed it so much.
if you answer this letter I will just about get it before we leave S.A. so whoop it up and answer. We met so many nice people on the boat and on our unclear night we rec'd loads of telegrams from them. I like it so well down here I would like to stay. They are trying to arrange for us to see a native dance. Won't that be glorious? If we get to see it I will write you all about it. I met some one on the boat I liked an awful lot but he is an Englishman so thats that. If he were American I'm afraid you would be getting rid of one of your daughters but

3.
England is one place I wouldn't live in and besides he was first officer on the boat so all I'd have to drag home would be something like that?  Eh what? Dont worry about me because I'm not going to do anything rash. I like the statue of Liberty to well.
Well write and dish me all the dirt.
Love
Grace
Empire Theatre
Johannessburg
South Africa

July 4, 1972
Dear Aunt Grace,
Finally I have arrived at Kibbutz Hatzerim and what an experience I have had so far! Everything was rather boring until I reached Kennedy Airport. There my luggage was combed by security guards (and quite messed up!) and I was frisked by a woman guard. The flight was extremely smooth; we had two Kosher meals and a movie. At Lod airport near Tel Aviv the plane was accompanied by security trucks to the terminal - there were guards with suns on the roof of the main terminal and many inside keeping close watch on all the passengers. Evidently many of these security measures were just adopted after the recent shootings by the Japanese guerillas just inside the building. Anyway, the Kibbutz is located just a few miles west of Ber-Sheva, so we are on the northern edge of the desert instead of smack in the middle, as I had thought. The heat is unbearable anyway so it really doesn't matter. My day begins at 3:45am. I dress and report for coffee + bread at 4:15. at 4:30 we head for the fields, where we are presently picking pears. at 7:40 we go back for breakfast, at 8:30 back to the fields, and we work til lunch at 11:30. Then our time is our own until 4:30 when we have Hebrew lessons til 6:30, dinner, and an hour or two before we all fall into bed again. I say "we" because there are 23 Americans all living in cabins at one end of the Kibbutz. By the way , the Israelis cook the way you do -> they eat their big meal at noon and moderate ones for breakfast and dinner. So far I have shared my toilet cubicle with a toad, a dragonfly, several roaches, ants, and have been accompanied by a bat that lives in the palm tree by my door and several lizards who inhabit the cacti living the path to the bathroom. I still haven't  figured out which ear my pet mosquito prefers to buzz around at night (the only reason he doesn't get away farther is because I have my sheet pulled up to my neck!) Despite these minor little draw-backs the place is really fairly modern. They have hot + cold water, cars, modern machines for the fields, excellent food, T.V., built in sprinkling system, electricity and so on. I may not be at the Hilton but I am getting healthy and am happy and learning so much. I will write soon. The address on the back is my correct mailing address.
P.S. My pattern size is Misses 10. It sounds cute!
Love, Katlei

Ms. K. Davis
Kibbutz Hatzerim
Doar Ha negev, Israel

July 15, 1972
Dear Aunt Grace,
Presently I'm lying on the grass by the built in pool at the Kibbety. This place is truly a garden of Eden in the middle of nowhere. There is an abundance of green grass, beautiful flowers and palm trees but outside of the Kibbety nothing for miles but sand and rocks. Last Saturday I went to the beach at Ashkelom on the Mediterranean. It only took two hours for me to get a lobster-red sunburn! I've finally healed enough to go back outside. The Mediterranean is beautiful but not much fun to swim in - the waves were quite high and the salt water is not exactly my favorite beverage. Thursday they held the Bedouin market in Ber-Sheva. I had counted on buying a smock with some of the embroidery on it that's supposed to be so beautiful. i was so disappointed!! Most of it is machine-made and very poorly at that - they wanted a fortune for it, even after trying to talk them down! It was interesting though. The Bedouins were selling piles and piles of marijuana and hashish right out in the open - evidently they are exempt from Israeli law. You could smell the stuff in the air so they were undoubtedly smoking it too. There were camels, goats, sheep, chicken and cows being sold, piles of vegetables of all kinds, and quite an assortment of souvenireers and other miscellaneous junk. Alot of the younger girls got a little upset when the Bedouins offered to "help" them try on smocks - their fingers just got just a little too long, and the girls didn't quite know what to do. We are still picking pears during the day, and, I might add, in our sleep too!! Someone "heard" that we were going to switch to peaches next week and the place nearly went crazy with excitement. The days are going by so slowly. I have heard from no one in the states. There is so much to tell you about when I get back - I can never remember who I told what, but I could sit for just days and talk about this place.    Love, Kathi

PART ONE

1972 July 31
Dear Aunt Grace,
I recieved your most welcome letter after returning from a three-day tour of the Judean Desert and Jerusalem. What a trip it was! We went first of all directly east to Masada on the Dead Sea. I don't know if you've ever heard of it, but Masada is a huge, flat-topped mountain which was the last fortress to be taken by the Romans in 73 AD. Herod built two gorgeous palaces there --- the ruins consist mostly of broken columns, fragments of wall frescoes and floor mosaics, but they give you a good idea of how beautiful it all must have been. It is of special meaning to most Jews because the zealots who lived there all chose suicide (1000 of them) rather than capture by the Romans. To this day every Israeli soldier recites in his oath, "Masada shall not fall again!" From there we moved northward to Engeddy Ein Gedi, an oasis in the midst of the mountains. If I didn't know better I would have sworn it was the Garden of Eden. You have to work to get there and really know where you're going (our guide was excellent!) because you'd never know it was there otherwise. It was well shaded by the mountains; there were little pools, bubbling brooks, waterfalls (some of them were small enough that we could slide down them in our swimsuits), caves with hanging moss, tiny flowers and trees. The water was as clear as what you'd run in a tub and was safe even to drink. It was just like something from a fairytale! From there we went to Nahal Arugot, another oasis, and then to Qumaran, the city where the Dead Sea Scrolls were written and which sits in the midst of the 14 caves where the scrolls were found. All of these, by the way, were just yards from the Dead Sea, a few minutes drive from each other, and in previously occupied territory. Before 1967 all of it belonged to Jordan. There were Israeli Phantom Jets flying over the water constantly; you could in fact see Jordan on the other side of the Dead Sea. From Qumaran we drove through Jericho; it was the first "disappointment" of the trip since it is now nothing more than a run-down Arab refugee camp, but it was interesting nevertheless. We did get a chance to swim in the Dead Sea. The entire group was in hysterics!! Its the one body of water I can actually stay up in!! You can honestly sit on the water and float, read a newspaper or whatever. The water is so heavy that you can't drown and it is so full of minerals that it doesn't even feel wet. It was fun while it lasted but we all itched and burned (in a number of places) for a good 24 hours! From Jericho we went to Jerusalem, & ate dinner in an Arabic restaurant. They served a sort of salad with mint in it and something which look like cigar butts soaked in oil but turned out to be nice rolled in grape leaves! (CONTNUED!)

Ms. Grace Brown
Box 14
Hardinsburg, Ky. 40143
U.S.A.
Kathi Davis
Kibbutz Hatzerim
Doar Na Hanegev, Israel

Bedouin
short e
as in "Bed"
PART TWO

Then we had a nice dish with lamb shishkabob. On the whole it was all horrible but again, an experience. The only redeeming thing was the Coca-cola. It was real, honest to goodness Coke; the bottle was written in both English and Hebrew! Unfortunately we didn't get to see much of Jerusalem in the eight hours we were there. We started at the Citadel in the old city, saw a couple of Synagogues in the Jewish Quarter, the Wailing Wall, the Dome of the Rock (a beautiful mosque) and got to walk through (or should I say had walk through) the Arab market to get there. What a mess that place is!! We left Jerusalem at about 2pm and went to Bethlehem about a five minute drive away. Ive never been much of one for organized religion but I have to admit it felt good to visit someplace that was Christian rather than Jewish or Muslim. We walked through the Church of the Nativity, St. Catherines Church and St. Jerome's Grotto; all are connected in one. I saw the place where Christ was born, a place where he was visited by the wise men (the monks there said that Mary moved him to a spot a few feet away because the original birthplace was too cold & drafty). Right in front of the second place they had a stand of prayer candles. I lit four; one was for you. The icons inside were all faded but beautiful nevertheless. I'm glad I had a course in Byzantine Art before I left. From Bethlehem we drove back through Hebron and Ber-Sheva to home. Starting Wednesday we have four days to travel on our own and then another four-day tour. One of the girls I'm rooming with has relatives in Haifa. We thought we'd spend a day or two there and then return to Jerusalem for a better look. Ruthie is Jewish so we're going to split it up. Friday we watch the Christian Pilgrimmage down the Via Dolorosa to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Saturday we attend an Orthodox Jewish ceremony. We still aren't sure where the tour will take us (four days this time!) but I will definitely write and tell you all about it. Meanwhile I'm getting a little variety in my work schedule---the dining room and greenhouse---and still being "adversely affected" by and all the fantastic fruits & vegetables here. Your letters take 6 or 7 days to get here, so do keep them coming!
Love,
Kathe

color photo postcard
Jerusalem, Basilica and Gardens of Gethsemane

Shalom Aunt Grace!
I only had a chance to be here for two days, not even enough time to begin to see everything, but I did manage to follow the procession down the via dolorosa to the church of the Holy Sepulchre on Friday. I've also had a look at everything (well almost) that you see on the front. Our Hotel is in the Arab section of town and the one phrase I can now say not only in Hebrew but Arabic too is "Go Away!' I've really learned how to get tough!!     Love, Kathi

August 12, 1972
Dear Aunt Grace, 
I've just returned from my last tour of the country before I leave. It was really quite different from the first. We were given four days of free time from the 2nd to 6th during which time Ruthie (one of my room mates) and I went to Haifa to visit her pen pal and family. They are Orthodox, so it was quite an interesting experience for me. From there we went to Jerusalem again. I believe tou could spend a month there and still not see everything! We arrived on a Friday, just in time to follow the pilgrimmage down the Via Dolorosa to the Stations of the cross. It ended at the Chruch of the Holy Sepulchre which is built ouer Calvary Hill and the Tomb where Christ was supposedly buried. I walked through the Garden of Gethsemame, sat in the Church of the Agonies. I also visited the Tomb of the Prophets (cold, dark, and clammy!) which had to be the most hair-raising experience of my life. There wasn't anything in the tomb but tunnels and holes but the little old man who led us around looked like Bella Legosi reincarnated. He carried an old pop bottle filled with kerosene as our lamp and had the habit of walking behind us with the light as we made our way thru the tunnels. It was pitch black since it was all underground so we didn't know what to expect!! You could hear the bats squeak now + then but thank heavens they didn't come near us! The next day we visited the Israeli Museum - I saw the head Sea Scrolls and all the artifacts which they have dug up over the past few centuries in a lot of the places I've been so far. It was really quite exciting!! The tour they took us on after that was mostly geographical, we didn't see many historical sites - just road and borders. We started out going thru Jerusalem and northward to the Galilee. We stayed in Tiberias for two nights, between times they drove us around the new borders of Syria and Lebanon and through old battlefields + bunkers. Unfortunately we couldn't set into the Golam Heights for military reasons. As it stood the bus driver carried a pistol in his belt and the guide brought a sub-machine gun on board. So it must have been slightly dangerous as it was. We drove to the top of Mt. Gilboa, went to Capernaum where St. Peter lived, and saw the Mt. of the beatitudes. The last nite we stayed on the shore of the Mediterranean near Rosh Haniler and had a barbecue. On the way home we drove thru Tel-Aviv and Jaffa, though we didn't have time to stay + stop. Now I set to pick peaches til I leave at the end of the month. I'm still arguing with the Airline over my ticket so even that is not certain. Don't write anymore after the 22nd, that should be about right!    Love, Kathi

Enclosed you will find a certificate for a X-man package - send as much chocolate as will conform to the size of package. Wishing good health to all. I? am. Your devoted son, illegible Ms A. Browne 332nd Field Artillery Halqin? Co. U.E.F. P.S. I am no longer in the board?. Have been on the front for sometime. Will write letter soon.

Mack Browne

July 25
Dear Miss Brown
This bothering letter is meant for all four party?] & is addressed to you because your name comes first alphabetically. I hope you wont think it cheek. 
I wonder if any of you collect things, stamp, post card, etc.? Probably not because you have lively lives. I have a quiet one in the country & hobbies are [unclear]. One of mine is to collect the many different varieties of soiled gloves, & ? specially the fancy ones or those worn by interesting people.
It sounds easy, but it is not, because even those people who promise to let me have their worn out ones have got so into the habit of throwing them away that they continue to do so.  Others think I want them before they are finished with?. I don't.
You and your company will throw away many gloves, fair & odd ones, of many kinds, while you are in ? , probably more than the whole lot in my collection.
I shall not have the pleasure of seeing or hearing your company.  Will you instead very? kindly give me great pleasure? by letting my collection benefit by open visit?  I have none worn by your country women & wold much like to have

those worn by such a representative party. 
I enclose an envelope which would hold a dozen so of gloves, + if your company will allow me to do so I will send another later as I know you will throw away enough to fill many envelopes like this. 
If any or all of you help my collection, it would add greatly to the interest of the gloves to have the wearers name on them, but that would be adding to your trouble unless you always put it on or before wearing them.
Please don't think any gloves too much soiled for me. I much prefer the most worn ones because these show most of the wearers personality. 
I hope you are all enjoying your visit to this country + will return home intending to do all you can to strengthen the bonds between us for I am sure the worlds peace depends on our countries standing firmly to-gether + {unclear] as yours are a greater {unclear} than the work of many fair [uncler]. 
With best wishes for success to all of your {unclear} {unclear} 
J.B. Watson

Tuesday
The [unclear] tell me you will all be at the side pool Friday night after the show - I may come Wednesday - In case you decide to call Wednesday afternoon, please send me a "pneumatique" express letter as I am not at the [unclear] before 5pm. In event you can call Wednesday make it 5pm otherwise Friday after show. Your [Nittered?] [Jide?] Press Agent
